page.lettertext:
fol.216v
My Lord Tresorere to S
r
Thomas Bodley the 7 of July
1594
S
r
I have acquainted hir
Ma
tie
w
th
all suche letteres as I have receaved from yo
w
who
dothe allowe very well the Course of yo
r
proceedinges synce yo
r
departure and althoughe
the occasyon of this letter hathe his dependansye uppon yo
r
formere instrucyones
to Negotyat w
th
the
Stat
for
yo
r
some support toward
the actyone of
Bryttanye
whearin hir Ma
tie
was Ingaged before yo
r
departure, yet for asmuche as some
thing hathe passed synce that tyme, w
ch
is fyte for yow to knowe, I have thought
good bothe to acquainte yo
w
w
th
the same and what hir Ma
t
pleasure is, yo
w
should
doe in regard thearof hir Ma
tie
being advertysed of the strengthe of the
Kyng
of Spaynes
forces in Brittany besyd
the Conjunctyon of the leagers of that
province, of his greate preparac
o
n of Shippyng onely intended for
the
possesse Breste haven, whear he hathe on the one syd of the haven bulte
a forte whearin he spareth No Charge to proceede and fynding that w
th
out
a great force, is to be used bothe by sea & lande, whearuppon hir Ma
tie
sent
expresely,
S
r
Roger Willyames
unto the
Frenche Kynge
(after his Retorne latlye
made from
bre
Breste) to acquainte him w
th
the state of that place, and to let
him knowe that hir Ma
tie
ceaving the Immynent danger by the Lose
of that havene, and forseeing howe lytle advauntage any other place
in Bryttaynye wilbe, yf that be loste, did make to the kyng this propo-
sytyone, that yf he wold Resolve, and send downe suche an Army by land
of horse and Foote as beinge increased w
th
suche forces as shee Coulde
Convenyentely Spare myghte be able to mastere the Enemy in the feeld
and lykely to Recovere that foarte, w
t
out the w
ch
small fruite will arise
of the action taken in hand, that then shee wold send a Convenyent prop-
orsyon of shippynge to impeache the fleete of the Kynge of Spayne and
wold increase hir Nomberes, thear alredy one land in Convenyente pro-
porsyon, To this the Kynge hathe made Answere that he will send the
Duke
Montpensier
w
th
two thousand foote and one thousand horse out of
Normandy
w
th
the Additione of thos forces w
ch
be alredy in Brittany w
ch
aryse in his Accompt to three or 4 thousand foote more and w
th
all some
vj
C
horse w
th
w
ch
Nomberes althoughe hir Ma
tie
sees No reason to beleeve
that any greate thinge Can be done, yet is she Resolved to enter into som Course
howe to Obvyat this violent purpos, and Nowe resortyng to the Rememb-
rance of many offers made by the stat
long synce to second hir Ma
tie
for
the service in Brittany in a very large proporsyon even as by many letteres
of their owne it hath appeared w
th
one halfe of whatsoever hir Ma
tie
sholde
imploy hir Ma
tie
hathe
tyculerly delte w
th
monser Carone
their agente even
by hir owne mouthe speedely and seriously to move the stat
to put their
helping hand, w
th
asmuche foarce as they maye by sea, and w
th
other helpes
of munycon to serve to Recover the
sd
forte, w
ch
motyon hir pleasure is
yo
w
shold recomende as amatter Newely Nowe agayne Revived to yo
w
, &
that yo
w
doe acquainte the Stat
that the Queenes Ma
tie
dothe expecte presente
answer to thes demaund
, w
ch
by their Agente she hathe also directed to be by him
communycated to them
and so I byd yo
w
farwelle from the Courte at Grinwiche the 7
th
of July 1594./
Yo
r
loving Frende W. Burgheley.
Post script ut supra
I have moved the Queenes Ma
tie
earnestly fo r yo
r
Retorne but hir Ma
tie
consyderinge ther
uppon fyneshing of the matter of
Grunyngen
one waye or other thear will falle out
some Negotyacon betweene hir & the Stat
, hir Ma
tie
is pleased that yo
w
doe first
procure some answer to theis hir Ma
t
proposytyones and after sygnefye yo
r
ceed-
inge in all thing
, w
th
out returnyng untylle hir Ma
t
pleasure be furder knowne
yo
w
are to dealle w
th
the Stat
that w
th
what Nombers of Shippynge & men and w
th
what quantetye of munycon they will assyste this service of Bryttany that the same
maye wthout delaye be put in Execusyon, for hir Ma
tie
hathe alredy sente S
r
John Norrys
, w
th
all his powere alredy by land to Breste and hathe also sent certen
hir shipes of warre to discovere the state of Breste haven, & thearfore yf the stat
seariously mynd the good of this service by their ayde, the same will doe Noe good
yf it shalbe delayed./.
